name: Hurry Up!
description:
Hurry Up! presents players with six dice-y challenges – for example, collect three pairs, assemble a straight, roll all six dice for a sum of 20 or less – that they must try to complete. You have only 30 seconds for each challenge, and if time runs out before you meet that round's winning condition, then you score nothing. If, on the other hand, you succeed, then you score both the points for that specific challenge (5-50 points) and the sum of the pips on the dice that you collected. After six rounds, the player with the most points wins.

Included with five regular dice is one blue die, which is wild for some challenges and laden with restrictions in others. In the "dice sum to 20 or less" challenge, for example, the blue die must be a 6 and all the dice must be rolled together. Fail to get that 6 or break the 20 threshold, and you'll have to roll, roll, roll again...

name: Never Say...
description:
The object of the game is to describe a word for your team to guess without saying any of the forbidden words. Players divide into two teams and decide on a time limit for each round. Team A selects a player to give them the clues for a word printed on their word card. The player picks a card and places it in the holder so that they and Team B can see it but team A (the players team) can't. They then try to describe the word on their card without using any of the forbidden words. If one of the forbidden words is used and Team B spot it Team A don't score and play passes to team B. If team A correctly guess the word they score a point. The team with the most points wins.

Components:

40 x Word cards
Team score pad
Card holder
Rules

name: Wargame
description:
Wargame is a strategy game for 2 players. Playing time is roughly 20 minutes.

Each player has 13 cards ranked from 13 (Bazooka) down to 1 (Spy). Cards of a higher rank typically take cards of a lower rank, though there are some exceptions (Spies, for example, take both the Bazooka and the Mortar, while Shooters can sometimes be "turned").

A player first deploys his cards by placing them, 1 and 2 at a time, into the 13 spaces on his line. Once all cards have been deployed, players take turns advancing their cards into the combat zone.

What makes the game interesting is the ability for players to switch two cards before advancing one into battle. Each player can do this exactly 5 times.

The goal is to win 7 of the 13 battles in the combat zone, or win 4 adjacent battles. The winner will almost always be the player who most skillfully utilizes his troops, as there is very little luck involved.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Print & Play, Spies/Secret Agents

name: Burning Passion
description:
Every one at some point or another has a little dispute with their partner, but few people feel the need to patch up their differences by duelling it across every room of the house.

Being a professional warrior has it perks but also its drawbacks. You may be the strongest around but you cannot handle losing even to your beloved one.

So beat them down and make them cry for mercy, then you can gloat and enjoy life, whilst they have to clean the house and pamper to your needs.

Burning Passion is a game for two players using a standard deck of cards and two simple character sheets. Each player has one character sheet and a selection of cards. Players simultaneously play cards into different rooms of the house trying to win the battle in each of the five rooms.

For every victory the player gains in a room they score one point. The first to ten points wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play, Real-time

name: Linkology: Solar System
description: The Linkology game is a fast and fun card game that links science concepts together in a way that reinforces vocabulary and classification skills. The deck of 100 self-checking cards contains word cards and beautifully illustrated photo cards. Each player starts with a hand of 5 cards. One card starts the discard pile. On your turn, try to find a card in your hand that shares an attribute with the top card of the discard pile. For example, if the word card "bone" is on the discard pile, you could play the picture card of "skull" from your hand. If you don't have a match, you must draw a card to add to your hand. If you're the first person with an empty hand, you win.

name: 221B Baker Street: The Master Detective Game – Set #4
description:
An additional set of cases for 221b Baker Street. This package comprises cases #61-80 and includes case cards, a clue and answer book, and solution checklist.

61. The Adventure of the Gluttonous Gossip
62. The Adventure of the Well-Informed Thief
63. The Adventure of the Duellist's Challenge
64. The Adventure of the Dashing Psychiatrist
65. The Adventure of the Murdered Stargazer
66. The Adventure of the Missing Bullet
67. The Adventure of the Limping Tax Collector
68. The Adventure of the Kidnapped Heiress
69. The Adventure of the Headless Horseman
70. The Adventure of the Italian Letter
71. The Adventure of the Killer in Kilts
72. The Adventure of the Chessboard Monarch
73. The Adventure of the Little Green Men
74. The Adventure of the Staggering Cowboy
75. The Adventure of the Murdered Medium
76. The Adventure of the Trustworthy Teller
77. The Adventure of the Fallen Angel
78. The Adventure of the Novelist's Demise
79. The Adventure of the Yellow Crescent
80. The Adventure of the Benign Burglar
categories: Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Murder/Mystery, Novel-based

name: 4 Player Checkers
description:
User Summary

This checker variant features a standard checker board surrounded by a three deep starting space for each of the 4 players.

Play proceeds in the familiar checkers mode with the added complication that one faces challenges from opponents on the left and right, as well as from the one across the table.

Game features playing pieces in blue, red, yellow, and green. Playing board is 19"x19" and made of solid MDF.
publishers: (Public Domain), Current USA, Inc., Current, Inc.

name: Block War!
description:
It is the 22nd Century and in the vast and overcrowded Mega-City One, the populace are crammed into mile high tower blocks. Each one is a city in its own right, with hospitals,
shopping malls and parks. It is said that a citizen may be born, live and die in their block without ever leaving it.
But citizens suffer from high unemployment and boredom is rife. It is in these conditions that almost anything, no matter how trivial, may escalate everyday tensions between
neighbouring blocks into all out block war.
A block war is nothing less than an anarchic armed battle between opposing blocks. With only the judges able to put a stop to it before many lives are lost, or worse still, the violence spreads throughout the city - Block Mania! Now you take the role of a Mega-City block and must fight your own block war, dishing out the ultra-violence from the relatively safe perspective of your dining room table. The only hazards you shall face will be spilled cups of synthi-caf, your partner wanting to set the dinner or a knock on the door from the judges.

Object of the Game
You play the role of a Mega-City block out to win a local block war, through killing opponents, gaining objectives and morale boosting actions, with success measured in ‘Fighting Spirit’.
Winning the Game
The game lasts until one block has achieved a comprehensive victory, neighbouring blocks surrender, are wiped out, or when the judges arrive in force to shut the shooting match down.
It is helpful to set a time limit for play, say two hours. Once that time has been reached and the round finished, each player in turn order starting is allowed one turn before points are calculated and a winner decided.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Miniatures, Print & Play, Wargame

name: 4 Kings
description:
4 Kings is a card game for 2 to 7 players. It can be played with a standard deck of cards, or with the print & play cards (available in the links section).

The objective is to use the unique abilities of the cards you are dealt, (or the cards you choose, if using the Card Drafting variant) to capture other cards, while at the same time avoiding the loss of your own highest valued cards. If any player captures all 4 Kings, that player wins.

A player chosen at random will start out the game with a card of his choice. After this, each player attempts to use the abilities of their cards to capture opponents' cards in play while at the same time limiting the risk of losing their highest valued cards.

After playing a card, until the start of a player's next turn, his card is at risk of being captured. At the end of play, if no player has captured all 4 kings, the player holding the highest value of cards collected wins.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Deduction, Print & Play, Puzzle
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Olympiade
description:
In Olympiade, 2 to 4 players compete on 8 special boards representing the 10 disciplines of the Decathlon: On day 1, they compete in 100m, long jump, shot put, high jump, and 400m. On day 2, the disciplines are: 110m hurdles, discus throw, pole vault, javelin throw, and 1500m. Special dice, with red, green and blue faces, are used by the players to achieve their successful results in each discipline. The points on the red faces are valid for racing events, those on blue faces for jumping events, and the green faces for the launching events. Naturally, the winner, the super athlete, is the player with the most points at the end of the Decathlon.

Originally published in spielbox 1992 #3 for celebrating the 25th Olympic Games - Barcelona 1992.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Genesis
description:
In Genesis, players build the surface of a new planet.

Each player receives a pen of a different color. The board is placed in the middle of the table. In the first phase, the players, alternately, put a mark of their color on a free space on the board in order to show their ownership. This phase lasts multiple rounds depending on the number of players (7 rounds for 2 players, 5 for 3 players, 4 rounds for 4-5 players, and 3 rounds for 6 players. In the next phase, each player, on their turn, chooses a direction and expands their landscape in the chosen direction. The game ends when all spaces have been filled. The player who has occupied the least amount of spaces receives zero points. The other players receive points corresponding to the difference between the number of spaces they occupied and the number of spaces the last player has. The player with the most points wins.

Originally published in spielbox 1992 #4.

name: Ascot
description:
Ascot is a horse race betting game for 2 to 18 players.

The game consists of the game board (six racing lines – one for each horse, numbered columns, representing forwards or backwards movements), 6 horses in 6 different colors, 108 betting slips (each 18 in the colors of the horses), and 72 movement cards in a neutral color. For each horse, there are 12 cards (3x "+", 2x "++", 1x "+++", 3x "-", 2x "- -", and 1x "- - -"). The start position of each horse is the field of its respective line in the central column.

Each player receives six betting slips (one of each color) and an amount of the 72 movement cards (previously shuffled and distributed amongst them). The objective of the players is to give adequate movement cards to the player nominated as the game master in attempt to best influence the position of the horses during the race. Simultaneously, the players may change betting slips with each other, trying to achieve the best winnings. For that, the players are free to communicate among them and change both betting slips and movement cards. During the race, the players may give movement cards (face down) to the game master. After the game master plays five cards, they move the corresponding horses according to the played movement cards. The game ends after a predetermined number of rounds are played and the players receive points according to their bets. The player with the most points wins.

Originally published in spielbox 1992 #5.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Hand Management, Negotiation

name: Vorbeugen und Helfen
description:
Vorbeugen und Helfen (English: Prevention and Help) is a learning game for children to gain strength in dangerous situations.

Idea and aim of "Prevention and Help" is to caution children to crimes. Children should know what danger lays in several situations. They should

gain knowledge about these possible dangerous situations
experience solidarity and helpfulness
learn self-confidence
learn power of sustenance
learn to communicate


The possible dangerous situations may be:

DANGER AT THE DOOR
ENCOUNTER ON THE ROAD
A CHILD GETS LOST
AWAKING OF JEALOUSY AND TEMPTATION
BURGLARY AT THE SWIMMINGPOOL
BICYCLE BURGLARY
THE ORPHANT APARTMENT
PARKING VACATION CAR
INCITEMENT OF ROBBERY
BLACKMAIL
DANGEROUS MOTORBYC DRIVING
PLAYING WITH FIRE


How to play:
A tile is chosen and placed face-down in the middle of the table. Adjacent to it the pile of shuffled Prevent- and Helpcards. Every player takes 3 Prevent-/Helpcards (placing them face-up in front of each player), 2 prevent thaler and 2 help thaler.
When the tile is turned face-up the communication process starts.

The game components include:
12 game tiles about dangerous situations
72 Prevention and Helpcards
20 Prevention Thaler "Smiling Policeman"
20 Help Thaler "Serious Policeman"
Appraisal Chits
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Open Drafting, Simulation, Tile Placement

name: Dork Tower Dealers' Doom
description:
Dork Tower Dealers' Doom is an insert in issue #7 of the Dork Tower comic book. The game board depicts a game convention's dealers' room (in 3-D, if the provided booth backdrops are mounted and placed on the board). The players move around the board and attempt to purchase new games. Games can be taken from players by Game Zombies or Gilly the Perky Goth. This can be prevented by leaving the room to stow purchases, but this of course takes time.

At the end of the game, the value of each game is determined randomly, but the games are divided into tiers so that there is some predictability: third-tier games are generally worth less than second-tier games, which in turn are probably worth less than the one first-tier game, but there are bonus die roll possibilities, so that will not always be the case. Furthermore, the first-tier game has a very small chance of being a total bust which causes anyone owning it to lose the game.

name: Hinchliffe Guide to Wargaming
description:
User Summary:

A brief overview of the wargaming hobby including game types, scale, model collecting, painting, terrain construction, and gameplay.

The guide provides a very basic Napoleonic ruleset to get the player started on their first battle. The simple rules serve both as an introduction to general wargaming concepts (movement, fire, unit combat values, etc.) and a framework for the player to adjust and create their own rules to suite whichever time period they choose.

Published by Heritage Models, Inc., the guide was a marketing tool to help introduce new players to the wargaming hobby and their line of miniatures.

name: Sealed with a Kiss
description: Sealed with a Kiss is a game where girls collect kisses (yes, kisses!) on their boyfriend's photos. It works like this: Every player gets one of 12 boyfriend photos (these guys are hunks!). Anyway, put the photos in the frames and move around the game board collecting kisses. When you win a kiss, you use the special 'kisser' stamper to stamp your boyfriend's photo. But hey, life's not always great, is it? Sometimes you can lose kisses, take kisses, or even have to trade boyfriends. The first player to collect five kisses wins the game. It’s that easy and tons of fun!

name: High purpose man's age
description:
A multiplayer game covering the Bakumatsu era, from Blackship to Boshin war.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bakumatsu
"High purpose men" were anti-shogunate organisations
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shishi_(organization)

Playable from 3 to 6 players. Each player controls important persons of the era.
The game is played during 4 preparing war turns and a final Boshin war turn.
Victory is decided by collecting VPs during play. VPs are given according to status track and outcome of the Boshin war.



First edition: issue game of Wargame Japanese History #8.

Second edition:
1 rule book (color)
1 map (A3 size double-sided printing)
1 counter sheet (15mm square)
6 sheets of cards (54 cards)
3 dice (6-sided dice)Number of players: 3-6
Play time: about 90-120 minutes
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Hexagon Grid

name: Anima Tactics: Romeo Exxet
description:
Publisher Blurb:

Romeo Exxet, The Supreme Inquisitor, is the most preeminent figure in the Inquisition. His name is whispered with a mixture of fear and unconditional devotion. Every part of him, from a single strand of hair to the last drop of his blood, emanates true power.

As foretold in ancient times, he is the chosen of the light, the embodiment of the dynasties of the seven Beryls. Blessed since the instant of his birth, Romeo has always been a giant among ants. His natural presence is such that even the most powerful Inquisitors and elementals kneel before him and serve him as if his word is law.

Leader Warrior - Light Church - Level 75

Exterminator of Gods: Attacks made by Romeo against Characters with a medium or large base use his secondary Damage attribute.

Final Conflagration: When Romeo dies, he makes an attack on all Units within 3 inches of himself.

Dies Magna (Ki, Attack) - +2 Attack / +3 Damage.

Caedus Celestia (Ki, Attack) - +6 Attack. To use this attack Romeo must have 8 or fewer Life Points.

Pray (Special, Effect) - Place a "Miracle" token on Romeo. To use this ability, Romeo must sacrifice 2 Life points. Limit: Once per turn.

This pewter figure is unpainted and unassembled. Requires additional Anima Tactics figures to play.

name: Blizword
description:
Blizword - for 1-4 players
A simple card game of wordforming.
components: 52 cards + 2 cards of rules

Shuffle the cards and deal a 3x3 grid of letters face up between players. The remaining cards form the draw deck. In turn players remove letters from the grid that can form a complete word or the start of one. All letter tiles must be adjacent to one another in order: up, down, left, right or diagonally. 2, 3, 4 or more letters can be used.

To score a word, square the number of letters (for instance):
S T O R A = storage = 5 letters = 5x5 = 25 points

Players should keep their letters in word stacks in front of them in separate piles for easy scoring.

The current player then replaces the removed cards in the grid with new cards from the draw deck. Play until the 3x3 grid cannot be completely re-filled from the draw deck. Highest score wins.

Variations

Orientation Blizword: The orientation of the letters is important. You can only form a word and remove letters if the letters are in the same orientation. The letters H I N O S X and Z are the only valid in either orientation.

Solitaire Blizword: Beat your personal high score, removing sets of letters and replacing them as you go. Play until the 3x3 grid cannot be completely re-filled from the draw deck.

Advanced Blizword: You can only remove letters ONLY if they form the START of a word.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Word Game

name: Pictures
description: In Pictures two teams play against each other. One player from each team reads a definition from one of the 110 cards, 2640 definitions and six different categories and gets one hourglass of time to draw and have his teammates guess the correct definition. If they guess correctly they get to roll a dice and move their pawn forward. The first team to reach the finish line wins the game.
mechanics: Line Drawing, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Kaisermühlen Schmäh
description:
What it is: A game centered around Viennese dialect. Unplayable if you are not familiar with the German language in general and Viennese dialect in particular.

Aim of the game: Bribing the attendant of the "Gänsehäufel" (a forested sand island in the Danube with a large open-air bath) into giving you the last of the almost-sold-out lockers. The player who is first to successfully bribe the attendant wins the game.

How it is played: To bribe the attendant, one needs to collect three "Wirtshauskarten" (inn/restaurant cards). These are gained by moving one's player token to the "Wirtshausfelder" (inn/restaurant spaces) on the board. When a player lands on a "Wirtshausfeld", he has to interpret a "Wuchtel-Karte". Each of these cards contains a lighthearted comments in Viennese dialect and four sentences in standard German. The active player first tries to interpret the comment. If he is successful, he gets to draw a "Wirtshauskarte". If not, he may pay 200 "Kaisermühlentaler" (game money) to have one of the four possible translations read to him and to guess if the translation is correct. If he is successful, he gets to draw a card. The "Wirtshauskarten" have alcoholic strengths printed on them. If the card has the same colour as the player's secret task card, he/she can try to bring it to the attendant to bribe him. But at the bath's entrance, there is a policeman conducting alcohol checks. Depending on the alcoholic strength of the active player's cards, he either has to pay a fine, or the other player/s who initiated the alcohol check have to pay the cost for the check.
Other special fields on the board let players win or lose money (through gambling, staying at the office, selling or auctioning off "Wirtshauskarten" etc.)
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Planet Raiders
description:
Planet Raiders is an abstract strategy game.

The action takes place on a space-like board with 4 planets at the peripheries (populated by aliens) and player's spaceships in the middle. The objective of the game is to recover the spaceships.

In order to do this each player has 3 raiders and 5 rockets. Using these he has to form the crew of the ship by making prisoners enemy's raiders and recovering aliens scattered on the planets.

Once a crew is formed, the player must be the first to bring one of his raiders on his ship to win.

name: Cupeed
description:
In Cupeed, players want to be the first to build a 3x3x3 cube – dubbed a 333 cube by the publisher – from the parts available to them.

At the start of a round, the 27 wooden blocks – with each block being composed of 3-5 connected cubes – are laid on the game board. These blocks come in four colors, and all the blocks of a single color can be assembled into a 333 cube, although some are more difficult to construct than others. Each player receives a hand of five cards from the deck of 55 cards. Cards come in two types:

• Block card – which shows a color and a number from 3 to 5. By playing this card, you choose a block that matches the specifications on the card and add it to your collection of blocks.

• Function card – which allows you to take a special action on your turn: taking an opponent's block or forcing a swap with an opponent, choosing a block of your choice, forcing all players to return a block, and cancelling one of the aforementioned special actions.

At the start of the game, all players reveal the block cards in their hands, and the player with the lowest sum of numbers chooses blocks first, then the next player, and so on. Thus, each player will start with a different collection of blocks and possibly a different number of cards in hand. On a turn, a player first draws a card. If he has two or fewer cards in hand, he can play one card or end his turn. If he has 3-5 cards, he must either play a card, discard a card, or discard a block from his collection. If he has six cards, he must play a card.

The first player to assemble a 333 cube with no extra blocks and no protrustions or holes in the structure wins the round. The first player to win two rounds wins the game. If you assemble a 333 cube from nine blocks or in a single color, then you win the game instantly.
mechanics: Hand Management, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition

name: Martian Coasters: 5th Martian Coaster
description:
A 5th Martian Coaster with black squares and gray arrows is a special promo card that allows for a 5 player game of the Looney Labs game.

Martian Coasters is an Icehouse game playable with a single Treehouse set, a set of Martian Coasters (each with a colored 3x3 maze printed on it), and a standard d6.

The coasters are arranged in a square and the pieces are placed on differently-colored coasters.

The objective is to move the pieces of your color through the maze printed on the coasters and onto a goal square at the center of your coaster.

The game additionally makes use of the Treehouse die, allowing the players to reorient and move the coasters, creating a constantly changing maze.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move, Square Grid

name: Bluffing
description:
60 cards, 4 cards of each number from 1 to 15

This is what the Edwardians might call 'a round game'. Every player is given 24 counters and each pays three into the 'pool'. The starting player chooses a card and places it face down and calls "one". If he is believed, the next player must play a card and says "two", with each subsequent player calling the next number in the sequence of one to fifteen. At his turn, a player can challenge the card played by the previous player. If the card was wrong, various penalties take place (drawing more cards and paying two counters into the pool and two to the challenger. If the card was correct, these penalties now apply to the player who told the truth with his numbered card.
If a player gets down to just one card, he may retire from the game and claims half the pool. Each subsequent player who retires with one card also takes half the pool (of course, it will get smaller as each player retires from the game). If a player has no cards left, he takes the entire pool and wins the game. It doesn't say so in the rules but I assume that if no-one retires with no cards left, then the winner will be the one with the most counters.

name: Batteries
description:
"A game which uses ordinary playing cards in a new and fascinating way" Box blurb
Cards are played 1 at a time to activate pieces on the board. Pieces are moved to scoring positions and do battle with opposing pieces by stacking up in a line "battery" and overpowering the opposition.

name: Appalachian Rails
description:
The Game At A Glance: Appalachian Rails is based on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad and its march across the coalfields of West Virginia. The railroad went into receivership after trying to burrow through difficult terrain. It was up to Colis Huntington, one of the “Big Four” in the transcontinental railroad, wanted to use the C&O as a railroad to link with his West Coast empire. Additionally, West Virginia and surrounding states in Appalachia had a large reserve of natural resources which would form the revenue stream for the C&O for years to come.

Your object is to mimic (and beat) the C&O's success.

The game starts with the player taking a loan for money to pay for track and locomotives to haul goods. Play consists of rolling dice for each commodity in the board. Some commodities such as coal are more plentiful than manufactured goods. After the commodities are placed, track is built, link by link, using the railroad's treasury. Locomotives may be purchased which have a range of anywhere from 5-10 links. After this is complete, if a player is able, he may transport cubes to any market expecting them.

There are also markets in the game which decide the price of a commodity based on how often it is delivered and how often cubes are placed on the board. These values are staggered for different cities.

For those who have played a number of train games, this game could be described as a cross between Silverton and Age of Steam with a little bit of Prairie Railroads thrown in for good measure. The main challenge of this title was to create a compelling solitaire railroading experience. The game is extremely difficult to beat. I think it lives up to the challenge.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Simulation

name: Frontjammin'
description:
This is #7 in the Games on a Half a Checkerboard Series. Frontjammin' is a game like Backgammon, with its own twists. It also includes a variant using a King piece, which gives the game a bit of a Chess flavor.

In the game, players will roll two dice. If they roll 5-6 on any of the two dice, that counts as a single die roll that a player picks (1-4).

In addition, the game involves pieces being placed in columns and trapping their opponent's pieces. The smaller board also lends to an increased chance of a reversal of fortune.

name: Lerne München kennen: 300 neue Fragen
description: This expansion for Lerne München kennen contains 300 new trivia cards on the city of München.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: Schmidt Spiele, Stadt Buch Verlag Wolfgang Giesche München

name: Crossbones: The Swashbuckling Pirate Adventure Game
description:
A pirate's life adventure tale...

Crossbones: The Swashbuckling Pirate Adventure Game is designed for 2-5 players, ages 10 to adult, with a play time of approximately 30 to 45 minutes.

Introduction

Avast, me hearties! Tis yer discovery of a treasure map that beckons ye and yer mates on a swashbuckling pirate adventure. Ye shall set sail in search of gold, silver, jewels and other treasures... yet beware of stormy weather, ruthless pirates, and other misfortunes that await ye!

Gameplay Overview

Crossbones: The Swashbuckling Pirate Adventure Game ~ A pirate's life board game where players take on the role of pirate captains that race against each other to become the first and most infamous pirate to complete an adventure tale. Pirate captains advance through the adventure by a rolling a variety of dice to complete a series of event challenges or by seeking tactical opportunities to plunder.

Throughout the adventure, Captains may navigate their ship to explore for cargo and/or plunder for booty to boost their reputation and crew morale... yet, a limited supply of rum and cannonballs will require each captain to manage their progress and piracy accordingly to maintain a tactical range of attack or defense in their movement. And, like any good pirate adventure, Captains may just find something more than other seafaring souls cursing the waters... so, keep a weather eye on the horizon an' beware the trance of mermaids or Kraken attacks.

Now... ready yer sails... man yer cannons... an' ne'er give up the hunt fer treasure!

Join our crew!

"The only way for a pirate to make a living these days is by betraying other pirates."

~ Barbossa
categories: Adventure, Dice, Exploration, Nautical, Pirates, Racing

name: Zardot
description:
In this prelude to the Parlour Master Series of games, players must maneuver their 9 RHUES to capture the RHUES of their opponent.

The board contains 37 dots in 9 rows. The rows, each offset from their neighbours by half a dot, are 3, 4 or 5 dots wide. RHUES can move one dot to any adjacent dot. Movement will result in a capture if the destination is occupied by an opposing piece. Six dots are designated "safety dots", which, when occupied, will prevent the capture of the occupying piece.

The first player to capture all 9 opposing RHUES is the victor.

name: The Greatest Day Ever Game
description:
From the carnival, to the toy store, to a big beach party, find your friends and presents as you race around the coolest board ever enjoying the greatest day ever in this original and unforgettable matching game.

Object is to be the first player to match Your 5 cards with any of Your 8 friends and presents.

Contents:

game board
40 playing cards
15 friend cards
15 present cards
8 card stands
4 game pieces
1 die
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: The Wall
description:
In the city of Kayin, the decision was taken to build a wall to split the city in two due to diverging ideologies. Now is the time to decide where the wall will run.
Each player plays the leader for one side, vying against each other to get the most value to their side. You are using your influence to convince the undecided to join you, have important places on your side and important events in the city’s life happen there.
However, you need to find the right ways to exercise your influence. Will you find the inspiration at the right time? You will have to roll the dice to know and choose the ideas (Decktet suits) you keep wisely to take the advantage over your opponent.

In The Wall, players throw a bunch of dice, and then decide to use those for either taking influence counters or paying the influence value of one of three cards available at that time. The card then goes into one of three categories (People, Places, Events) on the player side, to try to take control of that category.
Players also have identical Action-card decks, giving them a random special action every turn.
In the end, whoever controls more categories wins the game.

name: Spy 51
description: This is the third 2-player abstract game from Susumu Kawasaki. Your goal is to put as many groups of spies in opponent territory as possible. Each turn you choose a line and place as many citizens on that line as number of citizens already on the same line. If there is exactly one space left on any line, that space will be filled up by spy automatically. Very unique abstract game.

name: Bundesliga
description: In this game 2 players play on a soccerfield with 2 teams of each 11 players. The game board has points and lines on wich the player or the ball "move". The same rules as in the "real" socder game apply. The players move the team members and the ball around as if they were running or the ball has been shot. To figure out how far the player and the ball can "go" one uses a "fight roulette" (loosly translated). It is a small can with two balls in it. The yellow ball indicates how far the ball will move and the blue how far the player can move one or more of his teamplayers. The playing time is 2 x 15 minutes.

name: Esatomo
description:
Esatomo is an Italian boardgame published only to be given as a gift to subscribers of "Topolino" (the Walt Disney comic-book in Italy) and other magazines in early '80.

Players should place transparent pieces on the board trying to "cover" the hexes with a number, i.e. scoring points.

In alternative, players must roll the special dice and place on the board corresponding piece, always trying to score points.

name: Monkeys with Knives and Guns
description: In Monkeys with Knives and Guns, players take control of a band of armed monkeys trying to gather bananas. Monkeys are represented by dice, and players roll dice, then determine which of their monkeys grabs a banana, kills opposing monkeys or horribly injures themselves with their deadly weapons. The player with the most bananas at the end of the game wins!

name: Tough Hombres: The Battle of Mairy
description:
Another game in the very popular and easy to play Blood and Steel series. Tough Hombres is the third game on famous battles fought during the 1944 Lorraine Campaign (Patton's Finest and Revanche: The Battle of Dompaire are the other two).

This battle saw the US 90th Infantry Division break the attack of Panzer Brigade 106 in and around the town of Mairy on 7-8 September 1944. The conflict resulted in the near destruction of the German panzer brigade, severely reducing the capabilities of the German armored forces before the up-coming Lorraine counter-offensive.

As the German or American commander, can you do better?

Components

An 11x17" map
168 un-mounted, single-sided counters
8 pages of rules and charts.

name: Lost Worlds: Dino Fight Series – Allosaur
description:
A spin-off from the popular Lost World Combat Book series. Instead of fantasy heroes, the players take the roles of fighting Dinosaurs.

Each player neeeds a booklet to play. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid determines the result (wounds loss, off balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one Dinosaur or the other expires.
mechanics: Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

description:
The game covers the Polish-German war campaign of the first days of the World War II. Players can take command of the German Army trying to defeat Poland as fast as possible, or play as Polish generals struggling to stop the German Army.
One turn is one day of war.

Every turn is divided into 3 phases:
- logistics
- movement
- fighting

Box contents:
- Rulebook including 3 scenarios
- 2 Boards (map of Poland and tactical board)
- ca. 200 cards (weather cards, fighting cards)
- lots of counters

name: Vehicles
description:
Vehicles is a quick, challenging worker placement game. Unlike other worker placement games which can take two or more hours to play, Vehicles is designed to take about 20 minutes per player. That means a game usually lasts about an hour and a half or less. It's also quick to set up and get going.

Each of your vehicles is a worker in this game and each has its own abilities. Move your Car to a land space to buy a part, or move your boat to the salvage where your car cannot reach. You can build additional worker vehicles. Will you build the fast rocket that always goes first but cannot carry cargo, or the sneaky submarine that can share a space with another vehicle?

Vehicles was created for The Game Crafter's first game design contest.

name: Little England
description:
The Kingdom is united no more! Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have risen up to invade their historical oppressor! 2-4 players take the role of the four countries as they carve up England for their own glory.
Primarily card-driven, players will play attack cards to cities of different strengths (including bluff cards) to wrestle control of the cities away from their opponents. However if more than two countries turn up for a fight, politics and alliances intervene as players make simple deals with those in the battle.
Every time a city is captured, the final points value of the city drops. After five rounds of play the country with the most control points is the victor.
Little England is a free print and play game requiring only five pages for the game (four double-sided) and one double-sided sheet for the rules.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Negotiation, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Point to Point Movement, Secret Unit Deployment

name: International Road Racing
description:
A replay game of grand prix motor cycle racing.

Players control all motorcycles in a motor cycle grand prix race. The game includes statistical data for every circuit raced in 1984, and for all classes of motorcycles, like 80, 125, 250, 500c.c. as well as sidecars.

After you have decided which race to run, you set up all the drivers (represented by cardboard figures). For every racer you turn up a card from a deck of race cards and compare the individual driver's rating with a table printed on each card. The card now tells you if the racers stay in the group of motorcycles they are currently in, if they fall back to the previous group, overtake other drivers within their group, or even catch up with the group in front of them. Mechanical troubles as well as possible accidents are also covered by the results of the card.

After a number of draws, depending on the racing course and class of motorcycles chosen, the race is over.

The game lets you replay any single race from the 1984 season or even the whole championship.

name: Fantastic Flyers
description:
45 playing cards divided into 15 Fantastic Flyers

Each player has 5 cards and is trying to make sets of 3 cards to make a flyer, by trading with the deck or the other players. When a player makes a complete creature it is placed on the table. The player with the most complete creatures is the winner.

The included flyers are Bat, Bee, Butterfly, Cockatoo, Cranefly, Dragonfly, Duck, Eagle, Flamingo, Ladybird, Owl, Pelican, Robin, Wasp, Woodpecker

name: Candy Wars
description: A simple wargame designed to hand out at Halloween time. The game consists of two cards, the rules, two dice, and some candy. The candy forms the units with different types of candy having different special powers. Defeated candies are eaten by the victor.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement

name: Galactic Adventure
description:
Theme: You're in the role of interstellar pilots who belong to a secret organization OMEGA which should reveal where is the Star Gate, using artifacts - remnants of extraterrestrial civilizations, and only then the gate opens. When the gates open player to win the spacecraft Guardian stellar gate.

Goal: To be first player to defeat Guardian ship.

Mechanics: Every player at start of the game own very basic space ship. He must upgrade it to Firefly version in order to find star gate and defeat powerful Guardian.
In game players have opportunities to assume role of seven different duties from different side of law, which can help them to get money which is required for improvement of ship. Also players must explore universe which is different in every game, opening faced down cards which represent orbital sectors.
Fights is resolved using the dices on very unique way. Dealing and preventing damage according to values players previously assign to different values of 6 side dices, which represent their weapon.

name: Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes
description:
Contents:
4 jigged game boards, 32 parts of the body cards, 1 spinner, 4 wild cards.
Each player tries to collect cards representing parts of the body. A spinner decides which colour card can be taken. The player must point to the part of their own body which matches their selection. The first player to collect all 8 cards, wins.
There are easier variation s for even younger children to play.
At times, the players must sing the nursery song "Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes’ in full.

"Head, shoulders, knees and toes, knees and toes,
Head, shoulders, knees and toes, knees and toes,
And eyes, and ears, and mouth, and nose,
Head, shoulders, knees and toes, knees and toes"

name: Pocket Quiz: Märchen
description:
This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

The title translates to "Fairy Tales" and the questions aer about that topic.

name: Pocket Quiz: Mythologie
description:
This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

The title translates to "Mythology" and all questions are about that topic.

name: Englisch für Kinder Teil 2
description: The question cards in this Quiz/Learning game come from the daily life of a child. The front side shows the german word and a picture. The backside of the card has the english translation and the phonetic writing of the word to teach the correct pronounciation. Furthermore there is a simple sentence which uses the word in and easy context, also with phonetic transcription and the german translation of the whole sentence. The children move now through the downtown New York.

name: Das große Familien-Quiz
description: 6.000 questions in three difficulties, the themes are technology, politics, sky & earth, history, nature, art and culture, sports and fun and general, players try to reach the golden finish spot as quickly as possible by answering questions in the colour-coded difficulty range their piece stands in. Correct answers allow movement, themes are determined by roll of the die.

name: Welt des Kaffees
description:
Trivia game with more than 200 questions about coffee, cultivation, roasting, different types of coffee and more. Players choose for each question how many points they want to make and how big a risk they are willing to take.

Aim of the game: Having the highest number of points after a certain number of question cards have been played (number to be decided by the players at the beginning of a game). Points are earned by correctly answering questions.

Gameplay: The starting player takes a card from the card stack, chooses a letter and reads the corresponding question and its answers. There are two types of questions:

- Questions with one to three correct answers: For each question, there are four answers. One to three of them are correct, at least one is wrong. When all the answers have been read, the players place their chip(s) on the betting boards for the answer(s) that they think is/are correct. Each player (including the one who read the question) can place up to three chips. Players who put their chips on one or more wrong answers don't get any points this round. Players with exactly one correct answer get to advance their pawn one space, 2 correct answers means advancing 2 spaces, 3 correct answers 3 spaces.

- Questions whose answers have to be put in the correct order: For each question, there are three answers. When all the answers have been read, players put their chips in the order that they think is correct (the chips are numbered 1-3 on one side). Players with all three chips in the correct order advance three spaces. Players with one correct answer advance one space.

name: The Blue Sea Deck
description:
Like an Empire Deck or Sextet Bridge deck, the Blue Deck is a six-suited extension of a standard French-suited deck. The additional suits are blue stars and squids.

From the deck's website:

There is a long history of six-suited card decks. In 1895, Hiram Jones added Bullets and Crosses. Other designers have added Rackets and Wheels, Crowns and Anchors, or Valentines and Kites.
The Blue Sea Deck stands in that long tradition. Here the fifth and sixth suits are the blue suits of Stars and Squids. You can use the deck for playing Bridge with six, for making the odds in Poker go haywire, or for tossing card by card into a top hat.

The deck consists of six 13 card suits, 3 jokers, and a few information cards. It does not include rules or an actual squid.

name: Das neue Geo Quiz
description:
The topic chips for human - natural - heavenly - terrestrial are sorted and laid out as stated in the rules, as are the randomly chosen and shuffled obstacle tiles. These obstacles can only be mastered by discarding of topic chips. The questions cards are sorted in order of the topics, but if so desired can be shuffled.

In your turn you are the questioner, you draw the front card and name the topic, the facts, the questions and all answers. Then all players in turn choose and name one of the answers. Then the correct answer is read. If you answered correctly you can either move your pawn or take a corresponding topic chip from stock. If you reach a face-down topic chip first, you get it. If all answer wrong, the questioner gets a chip. If you answer correctly "all wrong", you move one step and get a chip. A spot containing an obstacle tile may only be entered if you can discard 2 corresponding topic chips. The rules also provide for players who have dropped back very far.

name: Hounds of the Sea
description:
In the adventure, you and your friends (tha' be players later on) take on the roles of legendary privateers, shrewd buccaneers and other kinds of bloodthirsty scallywags. All of whom are tied together by the code and honour amongst pirates.
Both code and honour will be betrayed multiple times as the players plot and make mischief for and against each other. One adventure takes approximately one to two hours, including all preparations and planning, such as shuffling the cards, creating characters and making up the premise. The game is playable with just the cards, but you might find the game easier to follow if you use paper to make notes and count the crosses in the Davy Jones Counter. The game is all about having fun. Push your characters into complicated and fun situations. Curse like a scallywag. Cheat fate, act like a legend, and if the inevitable cold grave calls you - go with a bang.

Each player has a character. After creating the characters, you may use the cards and the adventure-o-matic to create a grand,
challenging adventure. All scenes start from a plot twist. The twists might be positive, helpful, funny or they might come in the shape of a challenge. Players respond to challenges by using cards from their hand. A player may play as many cards of the same suit as he likes, but the sum of their values must be at least equal to the challenge card’s value in order to beat the challenge. If the character is unable to resolve a challenge with the cards in hand, the situation might call for a betrayal. A challenge from another character’s action can kill a character, if the challenge winning player calls for it. However, challenges between characters do not need to be deadly: a character might try to seduce another or steal his hat.

Pirates never betray each other, or the pirate code, Well... at least if it’s not a matter of life and death ... Or if it’s not about love ... Or if there is no gold in it ... Or… well, you get the picture. A player calls for a betrayal, and asks for a suit. Even if the characters cannot die directly from the challenges, there is a price for failure and betrayal. Sooner or later the cold arms of the grave will welcome all pirates of the sea. There should be 12 empty slots in each character sheet. These slots are used to keep score of the character’s failures and betrayals. Each time the character fails a challenge, two X’s are added to the counter.
Each time the character betrays the others, one X is added to the counter.

And each time the character gets one or more X’s - a card is drawn. If the value of the card is equal or less than the number of X’s on the character sheet, the character’s days are numbered and he is doomed.If a character already has 12 X’s on the sheet, he is immediately doomed, when he gets the 13th mark.
A doomed character will die in any of the next three scenes. Players should not feel too attached to a doomed character. He might look pale or even ghostly or see omens of his death for he knows that the day is his last.

When and how does the game end?
The game should end if
• Adventure has reached its conclusion,
• You reach agreed time limit (Professional pirates recommend using 2 hour time limit)
• Players are too tired (of drinking Rum) to play on.

name: Goal! Game expansion pack: French Team
description: This expansion is packaged like a CCG booster. It contains 14 player cards of the French football team and one new special tactics card.

name: Dice or Date
description:
D.o.D. - Dice or Date is a board game that can involve a minimum of 2 to a maximum of 6 players, in a world populated by Nerd trying to get an appointment with Amata, the most beautiful and proud girl of the City.
Help your Nerd collecting treasures to finally cross the three different dates Gate (Amata's family, his colleagues and her friends) that lead to the beautiful Beloved and her cold disdain for our protagonists.
Through a fully illustrated game board, consulting and moving pieces of plexiglass, players can choose between 6 different Nerd (specialists in many subjects: horror, science fiction, comics, TV series, Internet and video games, fantasy) willing to challenge themselves through direct competitions, Events , crossroads of the Devil, Retail and Fortress of Solitude.

name: Oma, Tante, Anverwandte
description:
Oma, Tante, Anverwandte ("Granny, Aunt, Relatives") challenges players to remember the faces of multiple oh-so-similar relatives and reproduce them.

In a round, each player receives a portrait card, looks at it secretly for some predetermined amount of time (say 15-30 seconds), lays the card down, then tries to reproduce the picture as accurately as possible. Players score points for each element that is the right shape, and more points if elements are the proper colors.

Some portraits have more elements to remember than others, so while your scoring potential is higher, you'll have a tougher time keeping everything in mind. After a certain number of rounds, the player with the most points wins.

name: Tanzania
description:
It's been three years since the nation's unification. Rumours have begun to spread of a rare and precious gem, discovered in the Mererani Hills of Northern Tanzania.

In Tanzania, players seek to increase their fortune, skill and renown to attain the most valuable gemstones. However, collecting gemstones is no easy task! Players will need to use their limited resource and clever planning to surpass the competition.

The game ends once two of the four markets (columns) have closed, after which the player with the most points is declared the winner.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Worker Placement

name: Ataque Pirata
description: After the retirement of captain "White Beard", the crew of a pirate ship decides do rotate positions. Each round, a new player becomes captain and pick roles for everybody else. In order, the pirates take a treasure (pearls, diamonds, rubys, emeralds or rum barrels) from a hand of cards. Precious stones translate into victory points and rum barrels confer "special powers" to the players who hold them. But not all treasures will be banked safely - Spanish, French and English pirate-hunters will force the crew to discard some cards along the game.

name: Mein neues Leben
description:
Objective:
get a job, acquire 50.000 € and own 3 friendship cards
- moving by turn -
you start as an emigrant, trying to get all neccessary tools like visa, job, vaccination, change of residence ...
moving around you must follow instructions on cards to be drawn
if you've finished 'preliminaries' you are allowed to fly to chosen country (change from outer to inner circle)

Now you have to make money, friends ...
categories: Card Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Chez Geek: Promokarte Poker
description:
(User summary)

A promo card for use with Chez Geek with the following attributes:

Aktivität
Slack 1W6
Kosten 2

Pegasus promo card #02

name: In the Emperor's Name
description:
This fan made miniatures game uses the setting of Warhammer 40,000 but the game represents fights between squads with a leader and a handful of troops, each controlled individually. The statistics of each character are Grit, Fighting Value, Shooting Value, and Speed. Several scenarios are given or players can make their own. There is also a campaign system for linking battles.

The game turn is split into three phases- movement, shooting, and melee. The players alternate turns activating all of their figures in each phase.
categories: Adventure, Dice, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Rekorde im Tierreich memory
description:
Rekorde im Tierreich Memory is a memory and trivia game played with the tiptoi.
The game can be played in different modes. The goal of the game is always the same: to find pairs of animals.
Tha cards are laid out face down.
By turn, players touch 2 cards with the tiptoi. Depending on the mode, you hear the call of that animal, an exact characterization of the animal, or just some vague information about the animal, for example: "it can swim."
If a player picks two identical cards, he scores them.
After all cards are scored, the player with the most cards is the winner.

Besides the games, you can also just learn about the animals by having the tiptoi "read aloud" facts about the animals.

name: Die Lieben Sieben: Mein erstes Brettspiel
description:
Objective: be the first completing three rounds on the board
finishing the puzzle in front of you
- moving by turn -
a bit like Pachisi, but the game is designed for the very young ones - only 1 meeple -
roll the (six-sided-)die - move your pawn
BUT.. you only may move if you know the symbol/theme covered by vour pawn (memory)
if you meet another pawn you only may move (and hit) if you know the symbol the other is covering, too
if you've finished a round get one of 3 pieces you need to complete your puzzle
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Sprout
description:
Sprout is a cooperative game for 2 to 5 players that can be played with a Series: Shibumi set. It uses a 4×4 set of stacking spheres in 3 colors. It can also be played as a solitaire game.

The completed Shibumi pyramid symbolizes the branches of a cherry blossom tree that grow and prosper. They can sprout horizontally or diagonally upwards, but must not break or tangle unnaturally.

Aim: All players win by placing the thirtieth ball, thus completing the pyramid, without losing the game in the process.

Setup: Place all 48 balls (16 of each color) in the bag. Each player draws a ball at random and holds it so that everyone can see it. The player who first recites a haiku or poem about beauty plays first. Choose difficulty, Easy, Medium or Hard

Play: When a player's turn comes, he must place the ball he holds on any hole on the Shibumi board or on top of a 2×2 platform created by balls. He then draws a new random ball and play continues counter-clockwise.

In Sprout, unlike other Shibumi games, dropping a ball is not allowed. You never remove balls from the pyramid you build as branches of a cherry blossom tree cannot be cut by themselves.

Game Loss: The players lose the game in two ways
1) If, at any time, two balls of the same color on the same level are diagonally next to each other (break)
2) If, at any time, a ball is placed on an upper level and there are two balls of the same color adjacent to one in the lower-level platform (tangle)

Wish: During their turn, any player may use one of the team's wishes to put the ball he holds in the bag and draw a new one of the color of his choice. If you chose the Easy difficulty, the team has 3 wishes. If you chose Medium, the team has 2 wishes, while if you chose Hard you have only 1 wish

Etiquette: The players are generally not allowed to speak about the game, suggest moves and interrupt a player's thinking.

The exception to this are the ancestors. After a ball is placed, any player other than the player who placed it is allowed to appeal to an ancestor and explain, in a few words, why this is a bad move and suggest a better one. The player who placed the ball then chooses to take the ball back or leave it be.

Each player may only appeal to his ancestors twice per game. Beyond that he must silence out of respect.

This game is an entry for the Shibumi Challenge

Beautiful the trees
When winter leaves, spring arrives
Colors fill the land

name: Pinocchio e il pesce parlante
description:
The game includes a 3D representation of the Pinocchio's world (the village and the sea with the whale).
The players move their pawns to both the mainland and the sea trying to gain gold coins and, in the same time, trying to avoid the various hazards because a player could be eaten by the whale during the game. If the whale was selected, the player should listen to its message (there is a disc in it where there was recorded several sentences) and suffer the consequences.
At the end, the player who will have more gold coins will be the winner.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Jack goes to market
description:
A family trade game. Jack goes to the market with three cows. Trade them as best as you can, and when the market is closed, see how much you've made of them.
The goal of the game is to trade your three cows before the market closed. You can trade them for chickens, pigs or beans...
Each player takes his turn by trading one of his good with one good on any merchant stands.
When a merchant has the three of the same item in his stand, he closes it. When all the stands are closed, the game ends.
You gain three points for every cow, two points for every pig, one point for every chicken, no points for the bean, unless you have three of them, then you score 10 points. They are the magical beans of the Jack and the Beanstalk story.

name: Spree
description:
An n-in-a-row game with a twist for the Shibumi Game System.

The board starts empty. Two players take turns handing a ball to their opponent to place, either on any empty board space or on any 2x2 platform. A player may not hand their opponent a ball of the color just placed.

Example: Player 1 hands a Red ball to Player 2, who places it on the board. Player 2 may then hand a Black or White ball to Player 1, who places it on the board.

A player wins by making a full Black or White line, orthogonally or diagonally, on any level, on their turn. A Red piece counts as both Black and White. The winning line must contain at least one not-Red ball.

A full line on the 4x4 (board) level must be of length 4, on the 3x3 level must be of length 3, and on the 2x2 level must be of length 2.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-a...

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

name: Dino-Bump
description:
Playing Pieces: 1 Board, 6 Dinosaurs, and 1 Die

Begin The Game

Who Goes First: The youngest player goes first. After the 1st game, the winner of the previous game goes first. Play proceeds clockwise.

Begin the Game: Place all dinosaurs in the Dino-Bath. Roll 1 die and go forward the spaces indicated on the die, then follow instructions on each of the rocks. There is only 1 die used in this game.

Only one dinosaur can occupy any space on board at one time. The only place that more than one dinosaur is allowed to occupy, is the Dino-Bath.

Dino-Bump: When you land on a space that is already occupied by another dinosaur, that dinosaur goes back to the Dino-Bath and your dinosaur stays on that space. This move is called a Dino-Bump.

On a Safe rock, however, you are safe from a Dino-Bump. See additional rules for Safe rock.

How to Win

The first player to enter the Dino Cave is the winner! You can only enter the Dino Cave with an exact roll of the die. If you roll a number that is greater than the number needed to enter the Dino Cave, do not move forward. Wait until your next turn and try again to enter.

The rule is different, however, for the last Dino Jump rock. From here, if you roll a 1, then you enter the Dino Cave. If you don’t roll a 1, then go back number on die. See additional rules for Dino Jump rock and Last Dino Jump rock.

name: Dice Bowl Football
description:
Dice Bowl Football is a two-player game where opponents coach teams in a battle of wits.

The game comes with twelve special dice representing offensive plays, defensive formations, and special teams. Each coach calls a play, and dice are rolled depending on the calls. The offense chooses a play based on risk vs. reward. If the defense anticipates the play correctly, they roll more dice and have a better chance of stopping the offense.

There are no complicated charts to search through after each play is called. The outcome of the play is read directly from the dice. Quickly the coaches move on to the next play, and the action is never bogged down.

Despite this simplicity of play, the game contains all the moves and strategy of a real football game. Everything that can happen in football can happen on your game table, from Onside Kicks to Long Bombs. Aside from offense and defense, there are also dice for special plays, penalties, and kicking.

Includes everything you need to play a game: 12 dice with customizing stickers, card decks representing the playing field, scoreboard, and game clock, 4 scoring rings, 2 field markers, a large cloth bag, and instructions for playing.

The field is built by laying out the provided standard-size cards, which means that all components fit into a large cloth bag. This makes it easy to take Dice Bowl along to tailgates, picnics, and parties. Dice Bowl is a great family game with a nice mix of strategy, gamesmanship, and a little luck!

name: Anima Tactics: Al-Djinn
description:
Al'Djinn are ancestral spirits whom dared to defy the gods, they have been imprisoned and isolated as punishment for their foolishness. The Condemned, The Manipulators of Fate … many are the names of the Al'Djinn. The greatest summoners can still call them to Gaia. While they are constrained by the many rules imposed by their imprisonment, they can still use their demigod like powers to alter the destiny of the world in many ways.

Dark Summon Mystic
Level 40 version
Att: 3 | Dam: 1 | Def: 9 | Arm: 0 | LP: 13 | Res: 11 | Mov: 6/10 | AP 3/4
Cost to Summon: oo Affinity: Dark
Atman: 60 | **Bind: 1 | Stability: 8 | Shock: +3
Innate Abilities: Flight, Intangible
Truncation of Fate: Enemy units of level 40 or below in Al-Djinn's control zone can not use Gnosis points.
o - Absolute Change (Magic, Effect):
The Al-Djinn becomes a copy of any other level 50 or lower unit in play. Taking on all of its statistics and abilities (Attributes, Maximum Action Points, Recovery, Skills,…). However, it retains the LP and AP it had when it changed. At the beginning of the recovery Al-Djinn may either continue to copy the other character or may revert to its statistics and abilites (again maintaining LP and AP totals)
oo - Ash Slave (Magic, Effect):
Put a level 20 agent of any organization into play within the Al-Djinn's control zone. The Agent enters play with 2 action points. When the agent's LP reach 0 or less, the ability stops being maintained, or if Al-Djinn leaves the game then the Ash Slave is also removed from the game. This ability can be used multiple times to get multiple Ash Slaves, but each has its own Upkeep cost.
Upkeep: o

Level 50 version
Att: 3 | Dam: 1 | Def: 10 | Arm: 0 | LP: 16 | Res: 12 | Mov: 6/10 | AP 3/4**
Cost to Summon: oo Affinity: Dark
Atman: 60 | Bind: 2 | Stability: 7 | Shock: +3
Innate Abilities: Flight, Intangible
Truncation of Fate: Enemy units of level 50 or below in Al-Djinn's control zone can not use Gnosis points.
o - Absolute Change (Magic, Effect):
The Al-Djinn becomes a copy of any other level 60 or lower unit in play. Taking on all of its statistics and abilities (Attributes, Maximum Action Points, Recovery, Skills,…). However, it retains the LP and AP it had when it changed. At the beginning of the recovery Al-Djinn may either continue to copy the other character or may revert to its statistics and abilites (again maintaining LP and AP totals)
oo - Ash Slave (Magic, Effect):
Put a level 25 agent of any organization into play within the Al-Djinn's control zone. The Agent enters play with 2 action points. When the agent's LP reach 0 or less, the ability stops being maintained, or if Al-Djinn leaves the game then the Ash Slave is also removed from the game. This ability can be used multiple times to get multiple Ash Slaves, but each has its own Upkeep cost.
Upkeep: o

name: Think: Kids – Alles Gemerkt?
description:
The animals bring gifts to the party and the players have to remember exactly who brought what gift, and who owns what hat. There is little time to look at the 6 animal cards before they are turned face down.

A player on his turn rolls the dice and tries to guess the card pictured on the number rolled. If he's right, he takes the card and a new card is placed to look at and then turned face-down.

The player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Deduction, Memory

name: Mens erger je niet! Kermis
description:
Ludo Funfair. Ludo variant with a funfair theme.
Box content
Electronic rotating gameboard
4 slides in 4 colors
4 x 3 pawns
1 die

Goal of the game
The 1st player to bring his pawn from the slide to the center of the board is the winner.

In his turn the player rolls a die and depending on the color picks an action.
White: choose an action except opening a purple gate
Orange, pink or dark blue: open a gate of the same color in one direction to send one pawn a section ahead or backwards
Purple: use the slide to remove one pawn from the board

name: Red, White and Blue
description:
Contents
A wooden board with 12 indentations and coloured red, white or blue (four of each colour)
1 spinning top
12 balls

Each indentation has a point value ranging from 1 to 12. To start a turn, place the balls into the tray. In a player's turn, he selects one of the three colours and then spins the top. The top will make the balls scatter and some will find the indentations. The player scores the point value for each ball that has settled in the chosen colour's indentations.

The first player to reach 100 points or more, wins.

name: Monster Island Battle Pack
description:
From Publisher Website

Scout saucers. Crop circles, Fighter jets. And new kaiju of every description.

The Monster Island series of tabletop fighting games continues to expand. Keep up with the Monster Island Battle Pack, featuring printable color figures and counters for all the latest additions to the game, from deadly monsters to new human military units and alien invaders. Also includes complete dossiers and figures for five brand-new monsters created by Patrick Sweeney and Rob Miller, plus, for your reprinting needs, the original figure sheets from Monster Island and Escape from Monster Island.

You must have Monster Island: The Game of Giant Monster Combat to use this product.

This is a PDF product.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: Anima Tactics: Genma
description:
Genmar Pheriu Dhanyata is one of the few Devah left in the world, a true rarity even within Samael. Though she has little combat skill, her mastery as a summoner knows no equal. Even the Fallen Angel Jigoku no Kami has acknowledged that, with regard to the invocation of supernatural entities, Genma is his only rival.

Neutral Samael Mystic - Lv. 35+
At 4 | Dm 1 | Df 8 | Ar 0 | LP: 10 | Re 11 | Mo 6/10 | AP 3/4
Summon Level: 3
Affinity: Light, Dark, and Void
Life Link: Genma may redirect damage she suffers for any reason to one of her Summons in play.
ooo - Lasso of Unity (Magic, Effect)
Place a Bind Point on one of Genma's Summons in her Control Zone.
ooo - Vanish (Magic, Effect)
Remove a Bind Point from an enemy Summon in Genma's Control Zone.
ooo - Spiritual Beam (Magic, Ranged Attack)
Distance (12 inches). +3 Damage.

name: Voyager: Ai confini della conoscenza
description:
The game is simple: a sort of "treasure hunt". Based on the exploration and identification of two "mysterious" objects, the game recreates perfectly the basic concept of Voyager: exploring mysterious places to study mysterious things.
The aim of the game is unveil the "mystery". To do that you must identify an object and a point moving along a path of boxes to connect 15 locations on a world map. There are moves by launching a special die on which the face with 1 shows the logo (V) instead of the number.
If the die result is V can perform special actions.
The 15 places and 15 objects are depicted on maps.
During the game, players get Voyager chips that have a value between 1 and 3. Who gets the highest total wins.

name: Spinout
description:
SPinOut is a short game playable with the Series: Shibumi game system. It uses the 4×4 board, 15 white balls and 15 red ones.



RulesThe board starts empty. Two players, white and red, take turns placing a ball of their colour either on a empty board hole or stacking on a 2x2 platform of existing balls.

A player, as an alternative, can choose to remove a ball (white or red) belonging to a 2x2 platform that supports not more than one other ball on each higher level. If a ball is removed then any others that it supports will drop. Any ball that directly supports two or more on the level above is pinned and cannot be removed. The removed ball must return immediately to the board in the place left free by the top ball just dropped (spinout rule, as for a car out of control!). A player is not allowed to remove a ball if the other player just removed a ball in his turn.

Aim: the goal of the game is to create the most three-in-a-rows on the surface of the Shibumi pyramid (4 triangular faces). Rows can intersect but do not wrap around corners or edges.
The game ends when the board is full with the 30 balls. Players are not allowed to pass and if a player has not legal moves the other player ends the game by placing his remaining balls to complete the pyramid.
In case of a tie for number of three-in-a-rows, the winner is the player who has the least number of balls on the surface of the pyramid.

name: Proto-Typical
description:
"The A-Typical Card Game of B-list Inventions"

Proto-Typical is a "Simply Epic, Free-Market Parody." Everyone knows that what the world needs now is MORE STUFF! And what's the best kind of STUFF? You guessed it! NEW STUFF! You have just inherited a somewhat successful, multi-national corporation with access to a handful of cutting edge patents that will help you build some AMAZING NEW STUFF! Of course, it just so happens that your friends have also all suddenly (and suspiciously) inherited their own companies as well. Now, you must race to finish and begin production of as many prototypes of NEW STUFF as possible. The inventions are bizarre, corporate espionage is inevitable, and the profit to be made is unfathomable!

Proto-Typical is played with two different decks of cards:

The Blueprints Deck contains double-faced cards with the invention and its value in millions of Globos (The global currency of the future) on the reverse, and blueprints for the invention on the reverse. The blueprint also lists component types needed from the Resources Deck.
The Resources Deck contains single-faced cards, which are either component inventions listed by type, or other resources (Scientists, Venture Capitalists, Celebrity endorsers, Advertising Agencies).


Game Play:

Player performs one of three actions:
Obtain resources - Draw one resource card from Resources Deck
Build a prototype - The player plays all the resources needed for one buildable idea (this may include resources in the public domain and resources from your hand modified by scientists), along with any value enhancing resources. Player takes the buildable idea OBVERSE-SIDE UP and any cards used from the player’s hand and places them as the completed prototype into the player’s asset pool
Kill an idea - Permanently discard (obsolete) a buildable idea by placing it and one or more resource cards needed for it from player’s hand into player’s assets, REVERSE-SIDE UP. This is a liability. (Liability amount is the value of the idea less the resources used)

Discard or draw cards so that player has exactly 5 cards
Reveal blueprint if any are still available so that exactly 3 show.


Ending the Game:

Play continues until there are no more buildable ideas, i.e. all blueprints have been prototyped or obsoleted.
Each player then tallies the total of their assets by adding the $G values of completed prototypes (as modified by human resources), $G4 for each resource card and subtracting obsoleted ideas.
Highest score wins the hand.

name: MathSumo
description:
MathSumo mechanism is simple: the cards represents the results and sumos on the board indicate the numbers to multiply. The game is to get rid of his cards by moving a single Sumo at a time and play the card with the result of the 2 sumos.
Special cards allow players to participate in the course of the game.

name: Chameleon
description:
"Chameleon - the game where you can run and you CAN hide!

Chameleon is a new and exciting board game that is a combination of Chess, Draughts, Chinese Checkers and Backgammon. It is a game of tactics, cunning and ambush.

Plan your attack, secure your defence, strike when ready.

Chameleon is played on 6 colour game board and comes with 12 pegs, 2 'chameleon' die, a rules booklet and a strategy brochure. Each player (either black or white) plays with 6 pegs that are red, yellow, green, blue, orange and purple.

The aim of the game is to be the first player to move all six tokens from your 'starting grid' into your 'home base' whilst trying to stop (or zap!) your opponent from doing the same. If you're on your own colour you are a chameleon and can't be seen. If you're off your colour you'd better watch out!"
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Phantasmagoria
description:
The one of Japanese collectible card game that uses the Japanese anime art style. This game's art and theme is base on famous Japanese visual novels (PC games).

The main concept of the game is letting the Character cards join the battle and deal damage to the opponent's Character cards. Knock down 3 of them or an Ace Character card to win the game.

The card types in this game are
Character card, Event card, Item card, Battle card and EX skill card.

Deck construction has 3 parts: Main deck, EX skill deck and an Ace character card. Each player must have at least 60 cards in main deck and a Character card (total 61 cards). Optional, each player may have up to 3 EX skill cards for EX skill deck.

Unlike Magic: The Gathering, the Creature Cards in Magic: The Gathering have 2 values; Power value and Toughness value for attacking and defensing in the game. But in this game's Character cards have 5 values. Each value will be determine which is the Attacking Value or Defense Value by the Battle Cards. 5 Value are Force, Agility, Intelligence, Skill and Tranquility (This is unofficial translated.)
Example, one of Battle card determines Force for attacking and Agility for defensing. In that battle, Force become attacking value (power) and Agility becomes defensing value (toughness).

The huge amount of tokens are necessary to play this game for counting a damage in each Character card.

name: Le Grand Jeu du Peuple Migrateur
description:
"Winged Migration" in English
The game uses the principle of migration, you are a bird and you try to make your trip the best conditions, avoiding the pitfalls Racing game like Chutes and Ladders with cards events, issues, etc.

Each player is a migratory bird. The goal is to achieve complete its migration and reconstruct the puzzle bird as quickly as possible.
Once a player has met the six pieces of his puzzle, he must go to the finish to win the game having completed its "migration".

Player rolls the dice and move forward or backward
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Paint the Line
description:
Paint the Line is an abstract for two players that uses Looney Pyramids. It is played on two boards - a 2x6 movement board and a 3x6 scoring board. Three trees each of four different colors are set up on the movement board. The second and fifth squares in the middle row of the scoring board are blocked off.

At the beginning of the game, each player takes two small pyramids of two different colors from the movement board. Players will score points for the two colors they chose at the end of the game. After choosing colors, players take turns moving pyramids on the movement board in order to capture other pyramids. A pyramid is captured when another pyramid moves on top of it.
